column1: Oregon City is the county seat of Clackamas County
column4: located on the Willamette River near the southern limits of the Portland metropolitan area. Established in 1829 by the Hudson's Bay Company
column5: in 1844 it became the first U.S. city west of the Rocky Mountains to be incorporated.

column1: Known in recent decades as the site of several large paper mills on the Willamette River
column2: the city played a significant role in the early history of the Oregon Country. It was established by Hudson's Bay Company's Dr. John McLoughlin in 1829 near the confluence of the Clackamas River with the Willamette to take advantage of the power of Willamette Falls to run a lumber mill. During the 1840s and 1850s it was the destination for those wanting to file land claims after traveling the Oregon Trail as the last stop on the trail.It was the capital of the Oregon Territory from its establishment in 1848 until 1851
column3: and rivaled Portland for early supremacy in the area. In 1846
column5: the Oregon Spectator
column6: was the first American newspaper to be published west of the Rocky Mountains. Oregon City College was established in 1849 as a Baptist school
column7: but was defunct by the 1870s. Oregon City was the site of the Beaver Coins Mint
column8: producing the short-lived independent Oregon Territory currency in 1849.The center of the city retains part of its historic character through the preservation of houses and other buildings from the era of the city's founding.

column1: The town became the see city of the first Roman Catholic archdiocese in the western United States
column2: when the diocese of Oregon City
column5: with Archbishop François Norbert Blanchet as its ordinary. Its territory included all of the western United States. The population in the area of Oregon City declined due to the California Gold Rush. The population of nearby Portland grew
column6: and the headquarters of the archdiocese was moved there in 1926. In 1928 the name Archdiocese of Portland in Oregon replaced the former name. No longer a residential bishopric
column7: Oregon City is now a titular see.

column1: Oregon City has several neighborhoods represented by official neighborhood associations:
The Park Place neighborhood is in the northeastern corner of the city
column2: located on a bluff overlooking Abernethy Green.  The neighborhood includes a housing project
column3: as well as numerous rural properties. Park Place
column5: also includes unincorporated areas outside the city limits. First called Clackamas (a name that was later given to a community three miles (5 km) north)
column7: the community was finally named Park Place for a park in a nearby oak grove. Park Place was platted in 1889
column8: and a post office was established the following year. For a while the name was changed to "Parkplace."

column1: The Two Rivers neighborhood is the primarily commercial lowest-elevation area of town including downtown Oregon City
column2: the End of the Oregon Trail Visitor's Center at Abernethy Green
column3: and Clackamette Park. It borders the Clackamas and Willamette rivers to the north and west and Park Place to the east and McLoughlin to the south. I-205 runs through the north part of the neighborhood.

column1: The McLoughlin neighborhood is bordered by Washington Street and Singer Hill on the Northwest
column2: a bluff overlooking Abernethy Creek on the northeast and east
column3: and Division Street on the south.  It also includes extends to the west to border the Canemah district.  The John McLoughlin House and the upper entrance to the Municipal Elevator are located in this neighborhood.

column1: The Barclay Hills neighborhood lies between Rivercrest Neighborhood on the west
column2: the city limits on the east
column3: the McLoughlin Neighborhood on the north
column4: and Warner-Milne Road on the south.  This neighborhood is bisected by Molalla Avenue
column5: the former route of Oregon Route 213 before it was moved to the Oregon City Bypass to the east.

column1: The Canemah neighborhood lies along Oregon Route 99E
column2: and is a narrow strip of land sandwiched between the Willamette River and a bluff.  Canemah was once an independent city before being annexed into Oregon City. Canemah was founded in 1845 and was the portage site around Willamette Falls for many years. It was supposedly named after an Indian chief.

column1: The Rivercrest neighborhood includes Rivercrest Park
column2: and the residential communities overlooking the Willamette River to the west.

column1: The South End neighborhood lies to the southwest of Rivercrest Neighborhood.  It centers around the intersection of South End and Warner-Parrot roads
column2: and was the location of Oregon City's (now defunct) drive-in movie theater.

column1: The Hazel Grove/Westling Farm neighborhood lies in the southwestern corner of the city
column2: lying between the bluffs over the Willamette River and the unincorporated areas to the south.

column1: The Tower Vista neighborhood lies southeast of South End
column2: and east of Hazel Grove/Whistling Farm.  It is bordered on the east and southeast by Leland Road.

column1: The Hillendale neighborhood lies south of Warner-Milne Road
column3: north of Clairmont Way and Beavercreek Road
column4: and west of OR 213 and the city limits.  The former site of City Hall is located here
column5: as is the Clackamas County jail.

column2: centered around the elementary school of the same name
column5: and north/east of the city limits.

column1: The Caufield neighborhood contains those parts of the city located south of Park Place
column2: and east of OR 213.  Clackamas Community College is located here
column3: as is Oregon City High School.

column1: The town is divided into upper and lower areas. The lower area is on a bench next to the Willamette River. The upper area is atop a bluff composed of Canemah basalt
column2: which flowed about 2.5 million years ago from a vent 7.5 miles (12 km) to the southeast in the Boring Lava Field. For many years
column3: Indian trails connected the two levels
column4: but stairs were built in the 19th century. In 1915 the town built the water-powered Oregon City Municipal Elevator to connect the two parts
column5: which was converted to electricity in the 1920s. In 1952
column6: a new electric elevator was constructed with the specification that it was to be "as plain as possible and without ornament."According to the United States Census Bureau
column7: the city has a total area of 9.29 square miles (24.06 km2)
column9: 9.05 square miles (23.44 km2) is land and 0.24 square miles (0.62 km2) is water.  The major waterways of Oregon City include the Willamette River
column10: which flows along the northwest side of the city
column12: which merges with the larger Willamette to the north of the city.  The Willamette forms the boundary between Oregon City and West Linn; the Clackamas serves as the boundary between Oregon City and Gladstone.

column1: The Willamette Falls Locks in West Linn were the first multi-lift navigational locks in the United States and are now a National Historical Site
column2: no longer in use. The first long-distance electrical service in the United States originated in Oregon City in 1889
column3: transmitting electricity 14 miles (23 km) to Portland.

column1: Oregon City has a Mediterranean climate. The Mediterranean climate regime resembles the climate of the lands in the Mediterranean Basin
column3: parts of Western and South Australia
column4: in southwestern South Africa and in parts of central Chile. The climate is characterized by hot
column5: dry summers and cool

column2: Oregon City's economy has been dominated by the forestry industry
column3: until the decline of the Pacific Northwest lumber industry started in the 1980s. At its height
column4: several mills operated in the city and surrounding communities. The last paper mill in the immediate vicinity closed in 2017.

column1: With the growth of the Portland Metro region
column2: Oregon City has become largely a suburb of Portland. Tourism is a growing sector with the emphasis on the city's history and the major renovation of the Willamette Falls into a public-access mixed-use space through the Willamette Falls Legacy Project.

column1: Oregon City is governed by a Mayor and a City Commission composed of the Mayor and four Commissioners elected from the City at large for terms of four years each.Oregon City was the capital of the Oregon Territory until 1851; the following governors served during that time:

column2: provisional governor of the Oregon Country 1845–48
first governor of the Oregon Territory

column3: 1850–53.  During his term (and against his wishes)
column4: the territorial capital of Oregon moved to Salem.

column3: is served by the Oregon City School District
column4: a public school district consisting of 7 elementary schools
column5: two middle schools
column6: a traditional four-year high school (Oregon City High School)
column7: and an alternative secondary school. Several schools in the district offer bilingual English/Spanish programs. Oregon City High School is the third most populated high school in Oregon
column8: and is a state and national power in girls' basketball
column9: winning three consecutive USA Today girls' national championships in the 1990s.The city also is the home of Clackamas Community College
column11: and a public library that is part of the Library Information Network of Clackamas County.

column1: Museums include the Museum of the Oregon Territory and the End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center
column2: with costumed "living history" guides.  The Clackamas County Historical Society archives
column3: housed in the Museum of the Oregon Territory
column4: also include the incorporation plat for the city of San Francisco.  Clackamas Heritage Partners owns and operates these museums
column5: along with the Stevens Crawford Museum.  In 2009
column6: Clackamas Heritage Partners announced that it could no longer afford to keep the museums open.  The End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center was closed to the public indefinitely in September 2009; the Stevens Crawford Museum and Museum of the Oregon Territory
column8: continued to operate on a limited schedule.

column1: The End of the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center eventually reopened during the summer of 2013 with the support of grants and donations from numerous sources.The Stevens-Crawford Heritage House Museum is a 1908 structure with 11 furnished rooms; exhibiting furniture from the collection of the Clackamas County Historical Society to replicate an Edwardian era home and Progressive Era narrative. Other historical buildings in Oregon City include the McLoughlin House
column2: the Ermatinger House (oldest in Clackamas County)
column5: and the First Congregational Church.

column1: The Oregon City Bridge over the Willamette River
column3: is listed on the National Register of Historic Places
column4: as is the Oregon City Municipal Elevator.

column1: Oregon City has over 22 city parks.  One of the city's larger parks is Clackamette Park
column2: at the confluence of the Clackamas and Willamette Rivers. The park's features include RV camping
column5: and other recreational facilities.  Several community festivals are held there throughout the year.  Other major parks include Chapin

column1: Interstate 205 passes through the city's northern edge
column2: and is the only freeway to serve the city. In addition
column5: and Oregon Route 213) pass through or terminate in Oregon City. The former two serve the city's downtown core

column1: The Union Pacific Railroad mainline passes through the city. The city also has an Amtrak station
column2: which is served twice daily in each direction by Amtrak Cascades trains running between Portland and Eugene
column3: Oregon. The Coast Starlight (Seattle-Los Angeles) passes through but does not stop.

column1: There are no public airports within the city. A small private airfield is along Beavercreek Road
column2: south of Oregon City. Oregon City is served by Portland International Airport
column5: a general-aviation facility in the town of Mulino
column6: approximately 15 miles (24 km) to the south.

column1: The Willamette River in Oregon City is navigable to small craft
column2: and Oregon City has a thriving fishing and recreational boating industry. The Willamette Falls Locks allow boats to navigate around the falls. The Clackamas River is not navigable

column1: As part of the greater Portland metropolitan area
column2: Oregon City is served by TriMet
column4: with several bus lines which converge at the Oregon City Transit Center. Until 1958
column5: an interurban trolley line operated by the now-defunct Portland Traction Company connected Oregon City with Portland; remnants of this line are still visible (such as an abandoned bridge across the Clackamas River
column6: just east of the OR 99E bridge). In more recent years
column7: the city operated a "historic trolley" service during the summer months
column8: primarily to serve the needs of tourism
column9: but the vehicles used were trolley-replica buses
column11: and in 2013 it was decided to discontinue that service and sell the vehicles.Two other public agencies provide transit service in Oregon City
column12: supplementing that of TriMet. The South Clackamas Transportation District (SCTD) operates a route between Clackamas Community College on the south east end of Oregon City to Molalla
column13: about 18 miles (29 km) south on Oregon Route 213. Canby Area Transit (CAT) operates regular service on Oregon Route 99E between the Oregon City Transit Center and Canby. SMART
column16: connects to CAT in Canby. CAT also has service to Woodburn.

column1: Dial-a-ride service is operated by TriMet
column2: but CAT also operates within the Oregon City city limits for trips originating or terminating in the CAT service area. If transfers between TriMet and CAT are necessary
column3: they are accomplished at the Oregon City Transit Center (OCTC) at 11th & Main
column4: which is at the northeast end of the downtown area.
